displayed_text: Family Member: And we will have a number to call? Doctor: Oh yeah, yep. And I do want to mention as you’re talking about this, he’s also an Iron Man candidate. Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: So in our quest to always get you the most number of trials Mr. W____ that you’re eligible for, (HCP laughs) Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: - so that I know and everyone else knows how you’re doing, how you’re feeling – Patient: Um. Doctor: - so that your experience gets you know out there Family Member: Right now as I say… Doctor: Um hmm. Family Member: He to me… Doctor: Um hmm.

Patient: Tell the difference. I can tell the difference. Doctor: Oh, yeah. And we know you’re okay now ‘cuz we know when you’re not okay because it’s not subtle. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: When you’re not okay, you’re just being – peeing gobs of blood, tissue – we know you’re not okay. That’s not happening right now. So, we’re at this perfect window – Patient: Right. Doctor: Where we gotta make a decision – Patient: So okay, doc. So, let me -- Doctor: And that’s the key. Patient: Let me ask you this. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. I have an ache in my hands. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: Um. When I try to – if I try to go to the bathroom without takin’ a laxative –

Patient: Four. Doctor: Argh! I can’t even trip him off. Family Member: I know. I know. Doctor: Well… you might need chemo. Let me say that again. You might need chemo. Was that whiney enough for you? Family Member: Yeah. Well, at least you have something. You could’ve came in here and said, “Oh, we got nothing for you. Doctor: Oh no, I got tons of stuff for you. The question is when and how and how do you feel about that. Family Member: S___? Patient: I can live with it if I can do the infusion stuff up there. Doctor: Okay. That's a possibility. However, as anything else, we actually have a study. Half the group gets regular chemo, which is IV. The other group gets a pill chemo which is oral. I can't tell you which one you are. And of course, we need you to commit so that if you say there's no freakin way I'm gonna get chemo down here then don't do the trial, but it's a fifty-fifty Family Member: You don't want to come down here xxx do you? Patient: How often do I have to be here? Doctor: Well, chemo is once every three weeks. So if you're good, don't quote me because I botched up a thousand things today in terms of the schedule, which is why I keep my mouth shut half the time. But standard chemo is once every three weeks. Family Member: Oh that’s not too bad.

Patient: You know, I'm not retiring tomorrow. Doctor: No, we don't want to leave you hanging. Patient: I mean, I don't think I am. Doctor: Right. So you're not planning it? Patient: Yes. Right. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Okay. So I think, you know, depending on so you'll finish reading the consent, if it's of interest call M___ back and say, okay, their next step would be to bring you in and actually formally review everything and get blood work on that day- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: -and then decide if you know you're even eligible, or that you're even interested after you review it one more time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then if it's good, then they sign you and then we go, and if you're like eh I don’t know, and then we think of something else. No pressure. Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: All right. Patient: All right. So this is the best. This is the best option that you're thinking right now.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, So, it is also an infusion, and I’ll have to pull it up. Uh, I don’t know how often you have to be there, but it – there is a slot available. It says that, uh, it has to be people with bone disease only. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um, they used to say that you had to have only Abiraterone or Enzalutamide. Uh, but now, they have broadened it, that if you have had Abiraterone AND Enzalutamide, you can participate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that one would be an option for you. Um. It’s uncharted territory. Patient: No chemo drug, though? Doctor: It is more of a natural product, biologic drug that on, um, in animals and in cell lines looks active against prostate cancer. And, so, now they’re escalating the dose of this natural product. Um. Family Member: Is that, uh, a stem cell or cell therapy or is it a -- Doctor: No, it comes like from a, I--I’d have to look. Whether it comes from a seed cucumber or-- Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or a pine co—Oh, it’s—I’d have to look it up. But, it’s, it’s a natural thing that, that, they have --- Patient: It’s organic medicine.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which why I told J___ let’s give it another whirl before you know you get too… Patient: Yeah absolutely. Doctor: …pooped out from the Taxotere. So I got M_____ on it. I’m just trying to look at your ankles over there. Just swelling more or what’s? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh, it’s just your socks. Okay. Patient: Just socks. She was checking I think for swelling. Doctor: Yeah. She’s pretty good. Patient: In fact I think um Doctor: Okay Patient: Dr. S____ put me on um oh what is it? It’s a, it must be a diuretic, but it’s I can tell you… Doctor: Mmm. Oh hydrochlorothiazide or Lasix? Patient: It’s not a Lasix or at least I don’t know (sound of zipper)

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that way if any questions… Family Member: You’ll come back today you mean? Doctor: Yeah. I do. Yeah, yeah. Family Member: I didn’t know if we have to come back. Doctor: I figured if he explained to you first and then if any questions come up and all that, I will come back. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s why I’m saying that that’s um you know I’ll do that twice just so… Family Member: Okay. Patient: You know I got an appointment with you later in June does that cancel? Doctor: No we’ll cancel that because we don’t need it. Yeah don’t worry about that. (Laughs) Patient: Well I was just wondering. Doctor: Yeah we’ll figure that out.

Patient: Yeah, I want to say I have maybe, yeah. Doctor: Okay. Because the other thought is Dr. S____ is here today, right? Healthcare Professional: Yes? Doctor: We have our own pain person. So, that way Family Member: Yay Doctor: if we have to transition, you’re right here too. Ah hah. So, you don’t have to Family Member: Right. Doctor: go running off somewhere. Okay, that sounds good Dr. H____, let’s do it. Patient: I mean that works for me. Doctor: Ok, that’s it. Patient: I mean since I got to come here anyway. Doctor: Yes and honestly I think your pain sometimes gets worse because you’re anemic Patient: Yeah, I mean it’s

Patient: Right. Doctor: It looks like there’s more now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I, I don’t think we could do that radiation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, just because of the number of them. Patient: Right. Doctor: We do, speaking of trials, we do have a trial coming up. It’s not open yet. But it’s probably going to be a trial after, uh, uh, actually, let me, let me take a step back. The other trial I didn’t tell you. We do have one other trial, uh, that involves, uh, a combination of two things. Uh, one is called, radium. And radium is a radioactive element that looks like calcium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the idea is we can trick the cancer, because prostate cancer is making, stimulating the bone to make new bone. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we give this radium that looks like calcium, so he gets put in there also, and can give radiation kind of focally. So where there’s spots on the bone, it gives radiation, but it doesn’t radiate the liver or the lung. Patient: Right. Right.

Family Member 1: About three times a week. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: He asolutely loves her. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: And he was letting her eat off of him like if he took a bite of his own now. Doctor: That’s a no. Family Member 1: Yeah. Patient: I stopped doing that quite a while ago. Family Member 1: Yeah, that's what he said about a couple of weeks ago. He stopped. He's giving her separated. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Okay, now, M_____'s pregnant, she picked up his water and drank the whole water the other day by accident. I don't know. Doctor: That's okay. Yeah, I think where when you're on chemo, you have to use universal precautions, you know. So it's always easier if you have more than one bathroom in your home. So that even if you have your own bathroom space where your towels and you can have Lysol and things. You feel comfortable. That's just his bathroom, so that you don't always constantly have to Lysol and Clorox things. Patient: Right.

Patient: You know I’m not trying to underestimate anything you know and you know because I never felt you know from the beginning I never felt… Doctor: Felt any symptoms. Patient: Yes. You know. Doctor: I understand. Neither did I. So we’ll get you to see Dr. R____ as soon as possible and I’ll see you back in three months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you get your blood test before you come back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Sound good? Patient: Thank you again. Doctor: Tell them before the end of July because I’m taking off June and July I’m having hip surgery. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So I’ll be seeing you though towards the end of July. Okay?

Patient: Keep goin’ with my pain medicine – Doctor: Take that as you need it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. Patient: And then – so we got that out of the way. Doctor: Got that out of the way. Patient: Then you’re gonna schedule me up to get the yoo-yoo. Doctor: The yoo-yoo’s the biopsy. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: He knows he has to have it. He knows he just had a scan. M_’s gonna go as quick as she can to get things rollin’. So. Healthcare Professional 2: Well, can you come Tuesday? (Laughs) Patient: Next Tuesday?

Patient: Well, well, I guess what I’m asking, if my PSA stays down - Doctor: The standard of care is – Patient: We should do nothing. Doctor: Is continue just doing what we’re doing. Patient: Eve—even, not even the clinical trial? Doctor: Right. One of the reasons for that has to do with, you know, how do we evaluate you on a clinical trial? What are our markers? PSA level? Patient: If, if, if, if – Doctor: So, if the hormones alone are making those get better, better, better, we give you the trial, I have no way to know did it do anything. So, we usually wait until the hormone stops working by itself. Family Member: And, that’s all just gauged by a PSA or do you do the – Doctor: It’s gauged by PSA as a screening and then, you know, at some point we would then just re-image you, too. Family Member: Hmm. Doctor: But, our experience is, as long as the PSA’s going down, usually the imaging is either getting better or staying stable. So.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Huh, so normally what you would end up doing is stopping the four pills. You can stop that. The prednisone you would stay on because we need it for the chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I think last time we talked a little bit about we have one clinical trial where we are giving men chemotherapy. Huh, that’s the standard. Huh, and then we, huh, ask men to participate and also getting vitamin C. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That’s the experimental part. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, the computer flips a coin and says whether you’re getting it or not. But you still would be coming in two times a week to get an infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That infusion could be real stuff, real vitamin C. Or it could be sugar. Patient: Okay. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Huh, so it really is asking a lot of you to give us extra time to sort out whether giving vitamin C makes a difference. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Tired. Doctor: Tired? How about the diarrhea stuff? Did it happen again? Patient: Um, hmm. Doctor: After the last chemo? Okay. Let me take a look at your belly. Patient: mumbling (sound of door) Doctor: Here I’ll take that. Remember to take it okay with you. Oh! Careful. Don’t lean on that chair. Patient: Ow! Doctor: That’s the same (speaking softly) Patient: No. Patient: Awww. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Okay so and you had quite a bit of this current chemotherapy that you’ve been on. Okay so we’ve given you about twelve cycles, but the good thing is it has worked and has kept the cancer in check all this time. The other good thing is that I didn’t see any other new areas. So the lung, liver, none of those were involved. Patient: Okay.
